📝 Assignment 3

Research Questions & Data Identification

⏳ Estimated Duration: 2-3 Hours
🎯 Due: Friday, 21 March at 11:59pm
Assignment Overview
This assignment will guide you through the process of formulating research questions and identifying and evaluating appropriate datasets for MDM analysis.

Using the framework explored in Lesson 4, you will:

✅ Develop 3-5 structured research questions related to your chosen misinformation narrative from Assignment 1.
✅ Identify at least one relevant dataset that aligns with your research questions.
✅ **Evaluate your dataset(s) based on structure, credibility, and reliability using systematic data assessment methods.

By the end of this assignment, you will have a well-defined research direction and a credible dataset to use for preprocessing and analysis in future lessons.

Step 1: Select Your MDM Narrative/Research Focus
Reflect on the two misinformation narratives you explored in Assignment 1. Choose one that you will focus on for the remainder of the course.
📌 Guiding Questions:
🔹 Which MDM topic interests you most?
🔹 Which narrative has sufficient publicly available data for analysis?
🔹 Does this narrative have measurable engagement (e.g., shares, likes, views)?

✍️ Write 1-2 sentences summarizing your selected MDM narrative.

Step 2: Formulate 3-5 Data-Driven Research Questions
Your research questions should be specific, measurable, and data-oriented. Use the framework below to refine broad ideas into structured research questions:

Broad Question

Refined, Data-Driven Question

How does misinformation about 5G spread?

Which Twitter accounts were most active in spreading 5G conspiracy theories between 2019 and 2021?

Who engages with election fraud claims?

What percentage of election fraud misinformation engagement comes from bot accounts vs. real users?

How effective is climate fact-checking?

What is the engagement difference between climate misinformation posts and their fact-checked corrections?

✍️ Write 3-5 structured research questions for your misinformation topic.

📌 Tips for Writing Strong Research Questions:
✔ Focus on specific data points (e.g., engagement metrics, amplification patterns, key influencers).
✔ Ensure the question is measurable (e.g., number of shares, sentiment analysis, bot detection).
✔ Keep it aligned with available data sources (e.g., social media datasets, fact-checking databases).
Step 3: Find Relevant Data Sources
Once you have your research questions, identify at least one dataset that contains the necessary information.

📌 Common Data Sources for Misinformation Analysis:

Research Question

Best Data Sources

Who were the top spreaders of misinformation?

Twitter API, Facebook Ad Library, Reddit API

How did engagement with misinformation compare to fact-checks?

Fact-checking databases (Snopes, PolitiFact, Google Fact Check API)

Did misinformation engagement peak at specific moments?

Social media APIs (Twitter, YouTube), Google Trends

What role did bots play in spreading misinformation?

Bot detection tools (Botometer, Twitter API)

✍️ List at least one dataset that aligns with your research questions.

Step 4: Assess Your Dataset(s) Using the Following Criteria:

Evaluation Factor

Key Questions

Source Reliability

Who collected this data? Is the source reputable (e.g., research institution, fact-checking organization, government agency)?

Data Accuracy & Completeness

Does the dataset include necessary details (timestamps, user interactions, context)? Are there missing values?

Bias & Manipulation Risks

Could there be selection or algorithmic bias? Were data collection methods transparent?

Freshness & Context

Is the dataset recent and relevant to your misinformation topic? Does it cover the full scope of the event?

Use these questions to analyze the credibility of your dataset(s) and write a short evaluation of its strengths and weaknesses.

📌 Submission Instructions

📌 Post a brief summary in the Assignment 3 Discussion Board with:
✅ Your narrative summary (1-2 sentences).
✅ 1-2 structured research questions.
✅ Dataset(s) you are using and why.
✅ A short evaluation of dataset credibility.

Bonus (1 pt): Engage with at least one peer’s submission by:

  • Suggesting an alternative data source OR

  • Recommending a refinement to their research question.

📌 Evaluation Criteria (10 Points Total)

Your assignment will be graded based on the following criteria:

Category

Points

Description

Research Question Clarity

3 pts

Research questions are well-structured, specific, and measurable.

Dataset Selection & Justification

3 pts

Dataset(s) are relevant, appropriate, and justified in relation to the research questions.

Dataset Evaluation

2 pts

Strengths and limitations of dataset(s) are critically assessed.

Clarity & Organization

2 pts

Responses are well-organized, clearly written, and free of major errors.

✔ Bonus (1 pt) – Thoughtful engagement with a peer’s submission in the discussion section.

To help with your data search and evaluation, check out these resources:

  • Misinfo Datasets by Complex Data Lab

  • Climatemist - Paper, Climatemist - data

📡 Technology Misinformation:

  • FaceForensics (Deepfake Dataset)

  • Hateful Memes Dataset

💡 Why This Matters

This assignment prepares you for upcoming lessons where we will:
✅ Preprocess your dataset (cleaning, formatting, handling missing data).
✅ Analyze misinformation patterns using real-world data.
✅ Develop data-driven insights on misinformation spread, amplification, and impact.

🚀 Get ready to start working with data hands-on in Lesson 5!
